title: 113_s2701
content: The Act titled "Stopping Illegal Obamacare Subsidies Act" prohibits automatic enrollment in health plans by American Health Benefit Exchanges until inconsistencies outlined in a June 2014 report are resolved by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. SEC. 3. PROCESS FOR APPLICATIONS WITH INCONSISTENCIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make public the steps to resolve inconsistencies in eligibility for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Monitoring progress methods will also be implemented within the same timeframe. The Secretary will make public the methods to resolve inconsistencies in healthcare program eligibility within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Monitoring progress methods for the Federal and State Exchanges will also be disclosed. Premium assistance tax credits and reduced cost-sharing programs will be suspended. The premium tax credit and cost-sharing programs will be suspended for plan year 2015 until all inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved by the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration and the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services confirms resolution of all inconsistencies. Requests for additional information may be made. Human Services confirms resolution of all inconsistencies in applicant information for enrollment in a qualified health plan. Requests for additional information may be made within a 90-day period. During the inconsistency period, individuals can enroll in a qualified health plan but cannot participate in the premium. During an inconsistency period, individuals can enroll in a qualified health plan but may not access premium assistance credits or reduced cost-sharing programs. If an individual provides additional information upon request and is later deemed eligible, they will retroactively receive the benefits they were eligible for during the inconsistency period. During an inconsistency period, individuals can enroll in a qualified health plan but may not access premium assistance credits or reduced cost-sharing programs. If an applicant fails to submit requested additional information, they will be withdrawn from the premium assistance credit program and reduced cost-sharing program at the end of the inconsistency period. During an inconsistency period, individuals can enroll in a qualified health plan but may not access premium assistance credits or reduced cost-sharing programs. If an applicant fails to submit requested additional information, they will be disenrolled from the program and must re-enroll with accurate information during the next open enrollment period. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "inconsistencies" refer to differences in self-attested information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and the data received from the Federal Data Services Hub or other sources, including citizenship and income. The term "inconsistency period" refers to a 90-day period after notice of discrepancies in applicant information for financial assistance programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is sent.
